bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, January 26, 1942

div1.p: Andrus appreciates Hench's comments and offer to review another draft of his manuscript, which he encloses. Andrus would like to see the manuscript published before his death.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, January 26, 1942
div1.opener:
From J. H. Andrus -
805 Cooper Street - Camden, New Jersey
Jan. 26, 1942.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter of the sixth and for the nice
things you say about my literary efforts. Any illusions
I may have had on this score have been shattered by the
promptness with which publishers bounce my brain child back
at me.

In your letter you say, “..if you would care to send me a
carbon copy of the second version I should be glad to go
over it page by page and send you such comments as I have”.
This is extremely kind of you and I appreciate it.

A copy of the last draft is enclosed. While the story
is essentially the same as the one you have, this draft
incorporates suggestions by Generals Kean and Truby and is,
I think, very much better for their help.

My story was written, originally, as a chapter of “Big Mo-
ments In A Little Life” - a one-volume (typewritten) account
of events memorable to the writer - for the probable amuse-
ment of my grandsons in years to come.

After General Truby sent his manuscript to me I got even by
sending mine to him. His comments were gratifyingly
laudatory and he strongly urged that I offer it for publi-
cation.

I rewrote it with that in mind and am accumulating a nice
little collection of rejection slips with an occasional
(publisher) letter just warm enough to keep the last glimmer of hope
from dying.

Yes - now that I have set out to find a publication to use
my story - I'm anxious to succeed. And I would like to
have it published while I am still alive and able to face
any criticism that might develop. As I will be bedfast
ten years the first of March, it will have to be published
soon if I am to see any back-fire.
Your offer to go over it page by page gives me new hope.

I suppose you saw General Kean when you were in Washington.
If you have never been in the military service you do not
realize what a distant planet a major is to a private.
That is how I knoe of General Kean when we were both in Cuba.
He has been extraordinarily kind to me and I would give a
great deal to meet him.
With many thanks for your kindness and with every good wish,
